headline: White House Picks Jeffrey Rosen for Deputy Attorney General
summary: The White House selected Jeffrey Rosen, the No. 2 official at the Transportation Department, to be deputy attorney general, putting a seasoned bureaucrat in charge of the day-to-day operations of a Justice Department battered by political storms.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Feb. 20, 2019

headline: Trump Eases Off Hard Deadline for China Tariffs
summary: President Trump gave his firmest indication yet that the U.S. may not increase tariffs on Chinese goods on March 1, as scheduled, despite statements by his top trade official that the U.S. should stick to a firm deadline.

headline: Queens Politicians Feel the Heat Over Doomed Amazon Deal
summary: Two Queens politicians who were critics of the deal to build a new Amazon campus in their districts have faced blowback from residents and business owners since the company ditched the plan.

headline: Pentagon Cloud-Computing Contract Sought by Amazon Faces New Hurdle
summary: A federal judge delayed a lawsuit over a massive Pentagon cloud-computing contract Amazon.com was favored to win while the government continues to investigate possible conflicts of interest in the procurement process.

headline: Federal Government to Cancel Funds for California High-Speed Rail
summary: The Trump administration will halt $928 million in aid and says it is considering legal action to recover federal money already spent. California Gov. Gavin Newsom called it “clear political retribution” over the state’s fight against the border wall.

headline: FDA Warns on Services Offering Injections of Young Blood Plasma
summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has warned older Americans away from services in several states that offer to inject them with younger people’s blood plasma as a treatment for dementia, Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease and other debilitating maladies.

headline: Chicago Police, Prosecutors Interview Brothers in Jussie Smollett Case
summary: Investigators interviewed the two brothers who purchased the rope used in the alleged racist and antigay attack reported by the “Empire” actor. Authorities also dismissed a tip suggesting the brothers and Mr. Smollett had been seen together.

headline: HSBC’s Profit Misses Analysts’ Expectations
summary: HSBC reported lower-than-expected fourth-quarter profit as choppy financial markets, U.S.-China trade tensions and Brexit uncertainty weighed on the global bank.

headline: North Carolina Election Officials Hear Testimony on Unseated Congressional Race
summary: In the second day of an election-fraud hearing in North Carolina over a contested congressional seat, a campaign consultant for Republican Mark Harris said he didn’t know a paid contractor was using unlawful methods in a get-out-the-vote effort.

headline: Teachers Strike to Kill Student Choice
summary: West Virginia’s GOP Governor surrenders to another union walkout.

headline: Bernie and Burlington College
summary: Sanders is no longer the only socialist in the Democratic crowd.

headline: Trump’s Emergency Is Test for Congress
summary: Letting the president conjure funds for the wall would damage separation of powers.

headline: Lyft and the Left
summary: The ride-sharing firm wants the feds to protect its business model.

headline: Vietnam Takes Aim at Radio Free Asia
summary: One of its writers is missing and another sits behind bars.

headline: Airbus’s Lesson for Young Socialists
summary: Its A380 debacle shows how hard it is for state planners to outguess markets.

headline: Why Service Is Lousy in High-Tax States
summary: There’s an almost inverse relationship between burdensome levies and infrastructure quality.

headline: ‘Earth-Shattering’ Review: Cosmic Calamities
summary: Great cataclysms can bestow great beneﬁts. A Mars-size planet once collided with Earth, creating the necessary conditions for life here.

headline: Beto O’Rourke Differentiates Himself From Democratic Socialists
summary: Former Democratic Rep. Beto O’Rourke, weighing a presidential bid, distanced himself from the Democratic socialist movement in his party’s left wing and championed free-market forces to achieve progressive policy goals.

headline: An Indictment Exposes America’s Witless Intelligence Agencies
summary: Monica Witt allegedly spied for Iran—but she defected in 2013, so she’ll never be brought to justice.

headline: Politics Has Become Boring Again—and That’s a Relief
summary: It inoculates us against the tiresome ideologue who wants to fix everything with One Big Idea.

headline: Is the Campus Free-Speech Crisis Overblown?
summary: Students assess the state of free expression in the university.

headline: Everyday Catholics Can Fight Sex Abuse
summary: Bishops have failed to police themselves. It’s time for the laity to step up.

headline: Notable & Quotable: Jussie Smollett’s Unraveling Story
summary: ‘I continue to hold a sliver of hope that...he was telling the truth all along.’

headline: Herbalife Sales Rise 9% in Latest Quarter
summary: Herbalife Nutrition, whose chief executive abruptly resigned last month, reported a 9% sales increase in its latest quarter, driven largely by growth in Asia Pacific.

headline: Ford to Exit Heavy-Truck Business in South America
summary: The auto maker intends to stop making heavy trucks in Latin America and end production at an assembly plant in Brazil this year.

headline: Payless Returns to Bankruptcy Less Than Two Years After Exiting Chapter 11
summary: As part of its latest bankruptcy filing, Payless will close all of its North American stores, while keeping its 420 Latin American stores and its international franchise locations open. The shoe retailer began to see its sales decline in 2015 and first landed in bankruptcy in mid-2017.

headline: A HUD Official Gets a First-Hand Look at NYCHA Woes
summary: Regional administrator Lynne Patton is spending a month at NYCHA apartments to get a view of the problems plaguing the public housing developments.

headline: McKinsey Settles With DOJ Over Bankruptcy Disclosures
summary: McKinsey agreed to pay $15 million to settle Justice Department allegations that the consulting firm failed to make required disclosures of potential conflicts in three chapter 11 cases it had advised on in recent years.

headline: Investors Sound Warning About Markets’ Complacency on Rates
summary: Stocks and bonds are rising on bets the Fed has ended its interest-rate increases, worrying investors who believe the central bank could upend those expectations later this year.

headline: Dollar Falls for a Fourth Straight Session
summary: The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the U.S. currency against a basket of 16 others, dropped 0.3% to 89.56. The dollar reversed overnight gains as developed-market currencies mostly hovered in recent trading ranges.

headline: Strong Results From Walmart Push U.S. Stocks Higher
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose, extending its recent rally after upbeat earnings sent shares of retail giant Walmart higher and President Trump further toned down trade tensions with China.

headline: Republicans Leading New Charge to End the Death Penalty
summary: Republican lawmakers in at least six states are pushing to eliminate the death penalty, signaling a broader reversal by many conservatives on an issue that has long been a bedrock for their party.

headline: Another Bernie Sanders Tax Hike
summary: As he begins another presidential campaign, the Vermont socialist promotes a plan to collect more payroll taxes.

headline: Space Force to Be Part of Air Force at First
summary: President Trump moved to create a U.S. Space Force within the Air Force at first, scaling back his ambition to establish a sixth major branch of the military.

headline: Clarence Thomas Urges Easing Standards for Suing News Organizations
summary: Justice Clarence Thomas issued a solo opinion urging his colleagues on the Supreme Court to consider making it easier for public figures to sue news organizations.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Can Make Rental Housing Less Affordable, Critics Say
summary: The agencies’ cheap loans help push up property values and attract investors to buildings in gentrifying urban neighborhoods, sometimes resulting in landlords boosting rents.

headline: ‘Botticelli: Heroines and Heroes’ Review: Harrowing Scenes of Women’s Sacrifice
summary: A tightly focused show in Boston centers on two panels in which the painter artfully orchestrates the ancient, violent stories of Lucretia and Virginia.

headline: Mr. Levy Loves but Misapprehends the U.S.
summary: Fair trade, lower taxes, less regulation and fewer foreign adventures aren’t hallmarks of the extreme right.

headline: President Obama Aided Democrats’ Identity Meltdown
summary: President Obama isn’t the voice of reason on identity politics. He is the reason.

headline: Don’t Write Off Elizabeth Warren’s Views on Banks
summary: The middle class is suffering and she is attuned to its plight.

headline: Self-Reliance Is Very Un-PC  But It Isn’t a Mental Illness
summary: Self-reliance, individualism and masculinity are code words in progressive academia for a dying patriarchal culture of male privilege.

headline: Shed No Tears for the LateMurderer Domineque Ray
summary: What accommodations were afforded the young 15-year-old girl who Ray raped and murdered?

headline: Is It 2019 or 1919? Baseball Is Hot Again
summary: Baseball, pelted with criticism for its long games and sagging attendance, is seeing a resurgence on sandlots, according to new data.

headline: Charlotte Russe Still Searching For Buyer as Possible Liquidation Looms
summary: The mall-based women’s fashion retailer has agreed to bid with liquidators, subject to better offers

headline: Fashion World Recalls an Influential Legend
summary: Karl Lagerfeld’s influence extended beyond the world of fashion, where he was hailed as a “modern couturier committed to the artistry of those traditions...with an eye for everyday life.”

headline: Lawsuit Over Location of Obama Library in Chicago Moves Forward
summary: A judge gave the green light to a lawsuit filed by a parks-advocacy group that aims to stop construction of former President Obama’s $500 million presidential center in a Chicago park.

headline: SEC Wants to Make It Easier for Companies to Explore IPOs
summary: Any company exploring whether to go public would get greater leeway to discuss their plans privately with potential investors before announcing an initial public offering, under a proposal from securities regulators.

headline: MTA Chief Says Congestion Fees Would Take Two Years to Set Up
summary: A system of congestion pricing in Manhattan could be up and running in two years if New York state lawmakers approve it as part of this year’s budget, top officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said.

headline: U.S. Government Bonds Gain Amid Global Growth Concerns
summary: U.S. government bond prices rose as investors are becoming increasingly concerned about signs of a slowdown in global economic growth.

headline: Appellate Court Rules Against Police Union Seeking to Block Release of Body Camera Footage
summary: A state appeals court ruled Tuesday that the New York Police Department’s release of body-camera footage doesn’t violate a state law that protects officers’ personnel records.

headline: Photos: Karl Lagerfeld’s Fashion Legacy in WSJ. Magazine
summary: On February 19, the visionary fashion designer—the creative force behind Chanel, Fendi and his own namesake label—passed away at the age of 85. See photos of Karl Lagerfeld’s transporting designs over the years (and pages) of WSJ.

headline: The True Confessions of a Serial Houseplant Killer
summary: How two horticulturalists and one life-affirming wisewoman saved columnist Michelle Slatalla from a lifetime of botanical guilt.

headline: West Virginia Teacher Walkout Kills Charter-School Bill
summary: West Virginia lawmakers killed an education bill that would have created the state’s first charter schools after teachers walked out Tuesday, one year after a teacher work stoppage sparked a wave of similar moves across the nation.

headline: Oil Hits Three-Month High on Saudi Cuts, U.S.-China Talks
summary: U.S. oil prices rose to a three-month high Tuesday, fueled by production cuts from Saudi Arabia and other producers and continued optimism over U.S.-China trade negotiations.

headline: The Fix Is in—DIY Repair Clubs Grow in Popularity
summary: The repair revolution is pitting tinkerers who want to fix their own stuff against product manufacturers who make parts and repair instructions only available to authorized dealers.

headline: Gold Surges on Elevated Geopolitical Uncertainty
summary: Gold prices surged to their highest level in 10 months, lifted by haven buying as investors monitored continuing trade talks and political uncertainty in Europe.

headline: Manny Machado, Padres Agree to 10-Year, $300 Million Deal
summary: Manny Machado agreed to a 10-year deal worth $300 million with the San Diego Padres. The pact is the largest free-agent contract in the history of North American sports.

headline: ‘Preminger Plays Preminger’ Review: Movie Music for Non-Cinephiles
summary: Saxophonist and composer Noah Preminger is not a film buff, but his latest release draws inspiration from director Otto Preminger.

headline: Egypt Denies Entry to New York Times Journalist
summary: Egyptian authorities denied entry to New York Times journalist David Kirkpatrick, an unexplained move amid a government clampdown on the media.

headline: NYU to Open New Medical School on Long Island
summary: New York University will open a three-year medical school on Long Island next fall, aimed at increasing the number of primary care physicians in the region.

headline: Medtronic Swings to Profit Despite Slowdown in Heart-Failure Treatments
summary: Higher sales of medical devices used in the treatment of brain and kidney diseases helped Medtronic offset a slowdown in sales of gear for heart conditions in its latest quarter.

headline: Ambitions for an ‘Arab NATO’ Fade Amid Discord
summary: American efforts to create a new alliance of Middle East nations to counter Iran are faltering amid regional divisions, a departure of key Trump administration officials leading the project, and disagreements over the group’s mission.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Clean-Water Case
summary: The Supreme Court agreed to take up a case that explores whether federal clean-water protections apply to pollution that passes through local groundwater, eventually flowing into the ocean.

headline: Fed’s Mester Sees Rates Slightly Higher This Year
summary: Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said she expects interest rates to rise slightly this year if the economy lives up to her expectation of solid performance.

headline: Roger Stone Is Ordered Back to Court Over Instagram Post Against Judge
summary: A federal judge is reconsidering Roger Stone’s release from custody as he awaits trial after the informal Trump adviser posted a photo of the judge with crosshairs next to her head.

headline: Kim Jong Un Purges Wealthy Elite and Critics of Outreach to U.S.
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has exiled, imprisoned or executed some 50 to 70 people and seized assets as he eliminates critics of his outreach to the U.S. and the South and targets the moneyed elite, says a report.

headline: Glencore to Cut Production at Major Copper, Cobalt Mine
summary: Glencore plans to curb production at one of its biggest copper and cobalt mining operations, Mutanda Mining Sarl in Congo, potentially taking a sizable portion of two industrial metals out of circulation.

headline: BHP Posts Big Profit Jump, Expresses U.S.-China Concern
summary: BHP Group’s 87% rise in first-half net profit sets the stage for what should be another solid earnings season for global miners, but the company  sounded a warning over the U.S.-China trade conflict.

headline: Car-Rental Company Avis Names New Finance Chief
summary: Avis Budget Group on Tuesday appointed John F. North III as chief financial officer, a move that comes as the car-rental company endeavors to boost its share price and its profitability.

headline: Customers Hunt for Bankrupt Crypto Exchange’s Missing Millions
summary: An unusual cash-pickup system is the latest unusual business practice at Quadriga to emerge since Gerald Cotten, the firm’s 30-year-old co-founder and CEO, died in India late last year.

headline: Courier Company BeavEx Files for Chapter 11 Protection
summary: Express delivery service BeavEx Holding filed for bankruptcy protection Monday and plans to sell itself to a strategic buyer, saying efforts to diversify its business after scanners reduced demand for paper-check couriers have resulted in sustained losses.

headline: For Royal Caribbean, a Good Ground Game Strengthens Sea Legs in China
summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd.’s efforts in China to establish cruises as a desirable vacation option are gaining traction.

headline: Hedge-Fund Giant Citadel Hires Manager Away From Her Own Fund
summary: Citadel, one of the world’s largest hedge-fund firms, has hired Samantha Greenberg away from her fund, Margate Capital. Ms. Greenberg is one of the hedge-fund industry’s few female founders.

headline: Danske Bank to Shut Estonia Branch Amid Money-Laundering Scandal
summary: Danske Bank is shutting down its operations in Estonia as the fallout continues from a massive money-laundering scandal that has led to investigations in several countries.

headline: Ballmer’s Head in the Clouds
summary: Former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer has struck a cloud deal—with Amazon.

headline: Pence Hires Former White House Aide Marc Short as Staff Chief
summary: Vice President Mike Pence has named Marc Short his chief of staff, making the former Trump White House staffer the first senior official to return to the West Wing after having left the administration.

headline: Holidays Were Joyous at Walmart
summary: Walmart nailed the fourth quarter, benefiting from growing online sales, struggling rivals and a strong consumer despite government data showing a weak holiday shopping season for retailers.

headline: French Jewish Graves Vandalized Before Marches Against Anti-Semitism
summary: Dozens of Jewish graves in eastern France were vandalized amid a recent rise in anti-Semitic acts and days after yellow-vest protesters were filmed accosting a prominent Jewish academic.

headline: Who Needs Free? Passive Fund Prices Flatline
summary: Despite last summer’s hullaballoo around Fidelity Investments’s zero-fee mutual funds, investors largely have appeared content to pay a little more, especially in turbulent markets, for strategies that can mitigate volatility.

headline: Bite-Size Deals Leave Brands Hungry for Growth
summary: Europe’s packaged-goods giants have taken very different approaches to mergers and acquisitions despite a common challenge: sluggish growth.

headline: Do AirPods Make You Look Rich? These Millennials Think So
summary: Fueled by internet memes, the explosion of expensive-yet-attainable AirPod headphones as the luxury item of the moment shows no signs of stopping.

headline: Tayari Jones Became a Writer After a Trip to Mars and a Year in Africa
summary: The author of ‘An American Marriage’ reflects on how her family’s experience with politics and travel influenced her

headline: Honda Plans to Shift Some U.K. Civic Production to North America
summary: Honda’s chief said he wanted to move some production of Civics to North America from a closing U.K. car plant, offering an example of shifts that may ensue after Brexit.

headline: A Coastal Home With Contemporary Touches
summary: A 11,759-square-foot house in Westport, Conn., looks out over more than 700 feet of shoreline on Long Island Sound. It is currently on the market for $12 million.

headline: A Life in Fashion: Karl Lagerfeld
summary: With his trademark dark glasses and slicked-back white hair, Karl Lagerfeld was arguably the most recognizable face in fashion, an industry he dominated for decades.

headline: ‘Documentary Now’ Returns With a Wink
summary: “Documentary Now,” the IFC series that parodies well-known documentaries, is back for a third season, with a cast that includes Michael Keaton, Natasha Lyonne and Cate Blanchett.

headline: Former North Korean Diplomat Warns of Deception at Coming Summit
summary: The highest-ranking North Korean official to defect in recent years said the U.S. should press Pyongyang to rejoin the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty as a step toward denuclearization and warned that the North would try to deceive with hollow concessions when the two sides meet next week.

headline: A Ford Thunderbird From the Good-Time 1950s
summary: Ford debuted the iconic T-Bird in model year 1955. This one is from that year, still driven in the town where it was first sold.

headline: Photos: An Icon of the 1950s
summary: An attorney shows off the 1955 Ford Thunderbird originally sold nearly 65 years ago from a dealership owned by his grandfather.

headline: HSBC Ain’t as Simple as Investors Might Like
summary: HSBC didn’t perform much worse than its rivals amid the market mayhem at the end of last year, but its 2018 results still gave investors a shock.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Walmart, Navient, Intercept Pharmaceuticals, and More
summary: Walmart, Navient, Intercept Pharmaceuticals and Mattel are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday’s session.

headline: Alibaba Takes Stake in Bank Backed by Tencent
summary: Chinese e-commerce behemoth Alibaba has joined online rival Tencent as a sizable shareholder in leading investment bank and broker China International Capital Corp.

headline: Amid U.S. Pressure on NATO, Europe Pleads for Caution in Afghanistan
summary: European governments, stung by President Trump’s barbs about NATO and sudden ordering of a military pullout from Syria, are urging America to coordinate with them on plans to reduce forces in Afghanistan and avoid a unilateral withdrawal.

headline: Investors Dive Back Into Italy Even as Recession Bites
summary: Italy has been one the biggest beneficiaries of this year’s global market resurgence, a surprise given the unease swirling around the southern European nation and its battered banks.

headline: Startup Pours Money Into a Bid to Reshape Construction
summary: Silicon Valley startup Katerra, backed by investors including SoftBank and FoxConn, hopes it can be a one-stop shop for building construction made simple. But the market has yet to see if the tech-focused company can deliver on its vision.

headline: CBRE Launches New Co-Working Business, Taking on WeWork
summary: CBRE Group and other big brokers are trying to muscle their way into the increasingly crowded but lucrative co-working business, aiming to help landlords create their own flex space companies that cut out middlemen like WeWork.

headline: SurveyMonkey Grabs Low-Hanging Fruit
summary: Investors never went bananas for SurveyMonkey, but positive changes are afoot.

headline: Acknowledge, Apologize, Investigate: How Brands Tackle Online Outrage
summary: If it feels like there is a steady stream of fresh outrage over consumer-brand gaffes, it may be because companies have become more adept at managing controversy than at pre-empting it.

headline: 5G Is a Winner for Chinese Companies—at Least at Home
summary: Companies like ZTE and Huawei are out of favor with the Trump administration. Beijing, though, is giving them a boost at home.

headline: Germany Posts Record Surplus, Bolstering Trump Claim on Trade Imbalances
summary: Germany’s current-account surplus was the world’s largest for the third year in a row in 2018, confirming deep disparities in the global economy that have drawn ire from the Trump administration and helped justify U.S. efforts to reset global trade rules.

headline: Party That Promised to Clean Up Italian Politics Finds It a Messy Business
summary: Italy’s 5 Star Movement rose from a grass-roots campaign against political corruption to an election-winning party. The realities of life in government since last summer, however, are putting it under growing strain.

headline: BHP: Everybody Hurts Sometimes
summary: Outages hurt results at BHP. There is little sign of fundamental problems, but the miner’s steady operations in Australia are a selling point compared with competitors investing in Mongolia and Congo.

headline: Trump Adds Senior Campaign Staff for 2020 Race
summary: President Trump added a new round of senior-level hires to his re-election team, continuing an early push to build out his campaign and preserve a clear path to the Republican nomination in 2020.

headline: Honda to Shut Major U.K. Production Plant Amid Brexit Uncertainty
summary: Japanese car maker Honda Motor will shut a major production plant in the U.K., the latest auto group to plan a pull back from the U.K. as Brexit looms.

headline: Carnival in Haiti: The Most Raucous Bash in the Caribbean
summary: On his first trip to Haiti, Joshua Jelly-Schapiro spends Carnival on the country’s southern coast, alongside rock stars and hundreds of mythical creatures.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Flynn Pushed Saudi Nuclear-Plant Plan Despite Warnings
summary: Former national-security adviser Mike Flynn and others in the White House ignored legal warnings as they pushed a plan to build nuclear reactors in Saudi Arabia, according to a House panel report.

headline: Sanders Announces 2020 Campaign
summary: Joining the list of candidates seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, Sen. Bernie Sanders vowed to take on “powerful special interests.”

headline: Can Anything Go Right for the 2019 Oscars?
summary: From hosting woes to fumbles over award announcements at the 2019 Oscars, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences can’t seem to catch a break.

headline: Hey, That’s My Idea! When Your Boss Steals Your Work
summary: Nothing frustrates employees more than a manager taking undue credit. Here’s how to navigate one of the trickiest elements of office politics.

headline: Walmart Posts Strong Holiday Sales Gains in U.S.
summary: Walmart’s profit and sales rose over the winter holidays, a sign that the retail giant lured shoppers from rivals and that Americans continued to spend freely amid mixed economic signals.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld, Chanel’s Creative Force, Dies
summary: German designer Karl Lagerfeld, who dominated high fashion for decades and reinvigorated French couture house Chanel as creative director, has died.

headline: Europe Again Champions Intervention to Counter China’s Economic Might
summary: Europe’s struggle to keep up with China’s government coordination of business and economic might of the U.S. has prompted more European politicians to advocate interventionism.

headline: How Airbus’s A380 Went From Wonder to Blunder
summary: Airbus touted its A380 superjumbo as “the Eighth Wonder of the World” when it was launched in 2000. But the 555-seat plane now offers a textbook case of a company misjudging its market and losing big.

headline: McCabe: Congressional Leaders Didn’t Object to Probe of Trump
summary: Congressional leaders briefed on classified matters had no objections to an FBI counterintelligence investigation into President Trump’s potential ties to Russia, former deputy FBI director Andrew McCabe said.

headline: When Bosses Call Walking Meetings, Some Employees Wish They’d Take a Hike
summary: The ‘walk-and-talk’ meeting is big—too big. The ambulatory group confabs force office politics inelegantly onto the sidewalk; ‘like a bunch of ducklings going down the street.’

headline: In Rebuke to U.S., Germany Considers Letting Huawei In
summary: Germany is leaning toward letting the Chinese tech giant participate in building its high-speed internet infrastructure despite U.S. warnings.

headline: Armed and Dangerous: How the ATF Retrieves Guns From Banned Buyers
summary: By law, a firearms purchase can proceed after three business days, whether or not the federal background check is complete. Federal agents are sent to seize guns from the people who should have never had them in the first place, including violent criminals.

headline: For Parents of Ill Children, a Growing Recognition of PTSD
summary: Post-traumatic stress diagnoses have long focused on combat soldiers. Now, doctors are increasingly aware of those symptoms in another group: parents of children with life-threatening medical conditions.

headline: Companies Roll Out Gunshot Detectors at the Office
summary: Corporate executives worried about workplace shootings are quietly installing gunfire-detection systems in U.S. offices and factories. Most don’t tell employees what the sensors are, for fear of alarming them.

headline: With Evangelicals Behind Him, Pence Takes Prominent Role in Foreign Policy
summary: In the first two years of the Trump administration, Vice President Mike Pence has put religion at the heart of key diplomatic efforts, steering hundreds of millions in U.S. aid toward Christians and other minorities victimized by Islamic State.
